comment._content: nice :)

comment.author: 38896199@N06
comment._content: Look at the beautiful VE bugs on the right! There's still a few around!

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: In Streetview, I see that the building at the extreme left is still a travel agency (Twohigs).

comment.author: 54431309@N03
comment._content: so amazing

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Purple Noon (1960) at the IMDb, starring Alain Delon.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Some history here, including the programme of the final show, the "Royale Finale", which was on Saturday 30th of June at 8pm, just three months after this photo.

comment.author: 60765183@N08
comment._content:
Agree that it looks they're showing like "Purple Noon" ("Plein Soleil") an early version of "The Talented Mr Ripley". 

Surprised that slipped through the censor's net.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: A soft evening in Dublin it seems?

comment.author: 63429800@N06
comment._content: Hawkins St. looked a darn sight better then than it does now. Where did we go wrong?

comment.author: 14099207@N07
comment._content: I wish I had money to visit the wonderful Emerald island!!

comment.author: 95412871@N00
comment._content: Unbelievably they knocked it down and replaced it with this monstrosity

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/turgidson/] That's the Department of Health, no wonder the system is in such a mess, they couldn't get their own building right.

comment.author: 24101413@N03
comment._content: Sorry, Swordscookie, but if I recall correctly, Hawkins House was built by/for the Rank Organisation, and for many years there were a number of private sector tenants as well as Government ones.  The OPW acquired it about 20 years ago, I think.  It would take a sizeable amount of money to bring it up to modern standards and I'm sure there would be a long queue of "knockers" if public money was spent on such a project!

comment.author: 58930216@N04
comment._content: I thought they were planning to demolish Hawkin's House now anyway and build something else in it's place? In any cast the Memorial statue will presumably have to find a new home soon as the LUAS tram connector is due to go along Hawkin's Street (they are building the new bridge across the Liffey for that at the moment!)!

comment.author: 24101413@N03
comment._content: Any plans to demolish and replace HH disappeared with the end of the building/speculation "boom".

comment.author: 95412871@N00
comment._content: I believe one developer had bought up the ugly troika of Hawkins House, Apollo House and College House and planned to demolish the lot but this is unlikely to happen now or anytime soon.

comment.author: 58930216@N04
comment._content: Can't see how SIPTU can afford to do what they plan with Liberty Hall either, in the current financial circumstances?!

comment.author: 38915126@N06
comment._content: Wonderful image and capture.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/photoken04] Neither had I (seen a colour shot), so I was delighted when I found it!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/60765183@N08] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Crikey! Purple Noon/Plein Soleil - Passion at Ten; Envy at Eleven; Murder at Noon. Mind you, it was released in France on 10 March 1960, so it had taken over two years to wend its way to Dublin...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 77073212@N02
comment._content: I have a good feeling about something.

comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content:
Spent years of my life waiting for buses in blustery Hawkins St. looking at the ugly underbelly of Hawkins House.
What a crime it was to destroy this theatre.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/eyelightfilms] Not feeling any love on here whatsoever for Hawkins House! I wonder if it's one of the most hated in Dublin...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 58930216@N04
comment._content: Wait until some Liberty Hall pictures go up....... I'd guess the feelings towards that will be as bad!

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content:
No, Liberty hall is ugly, but it is striking. It's not a success, but it's brave.

Hawkins House is just shite.

comment.author: 97828344@N00
comment._content: In HH's defence, Poolbeg Street is one of the most atmospheric streets in Dublin as a result of it - gloomy, canyon-like, bookended of course by the Ulster Bank HQ and the back of the former Gas showrooms.. There's nothing like emerging out of Mulligans in the teeming rain below the shadowy hulk of Hawkins House.

comment.author: 64848937@N00
comment._content: Hawkin's House competes with the motor tax office just over the bridge from Wood Quay for the title of ugliest building in the city.  The Tax Office does not look long for this world and you can only hope HH will follow it soon after!  Liberty Hall, on the other hand, has an originality that is engaging.  It just needs to be restored to it's original design and it will bloom on the Quays again.

comment.author: 58157940@N04
comment._content: I wonder if the tours to Dublin show these amazing places?  Our Parish Priest makes a trip about every other year to see everything....next time maybe, it is very expensive now & you have to have someone to share a room with, I am alone....so it is more money...but would love to see all the sights....
